persons.name: ThomasAquinas
persons.description: Italian Dominican friar and priest, an influential philosopher and theologian, and a jurist in the tradition of scholasticism from the county of Aquino in the Kingdom of Sicily. Thomas was a prominent proponent of natural theology and the father of a school of thought known as Thomism.

persons.name: Giambatistadella Porta
persons.description: Author of "Magia Naturalis", he was nicknamed "Baptista Porta" by Libavius.

persons.name: PedaniusDioscorides
persons.description: "the father of pharmacognosy", was a Greek physician, pharmacologist, botanist, and author of De materia medica a 5-volume Greek encyclopedic pharmacopeia on herbal medicine and related medicinal substances, that was widely read for more than 1,500 years. For almost two millennia Dioscorides was regarded as the most prominent writer on plants and plant drugs.

persons.name: Arnaldusde Villa Nova
persons.description: A physician and a religious reformer. He is credited with translating a number of medical texts from Arabic, including works by Ibn Sina Avicenna, Abu-l-Salt, and Galen.

persons.name: RaymondLoully
persons.description: Born Ramon Llull (anglicized to Raymond Loully), he was a philosopher, theologian, poet, missionary, Christian apologist and former knight from the Kingdom of Majorca.

persons.name: NicolasGuibert
persons.description: A Franco-German physician and alchemist who later became a fierce critic of alchemy, opposing ideas on transmutation.

persons.name: ThomasErastus
persons.description: Thomas Erastus was a Swiss physician and Calvinist theologian. He published several pieces focused on medicine, astrology, alchemy, and attacked in his publications the system of Paracelsus. In doing so, he defended medieval tradition in general, and Galen in particular, while conceding some merit to specific points in Paracelsus.

persons.description: a pharmaceutical chemist of the 17th century, the mineral glaserite is named after him.

persons.name: Marcus AtiliusRegulus
persons.description: Roman statesman and general who was a consul of the Roman Republic in 267 BC and 256 BC. Much of his career was spent fighting the Carthaginians during the first Punic War.

persons.description: Medieval English philosopher and Franciscan friar.

persons.name: EdwardKelley
persons.description: English alchemist and associate of John Dee.

works.name: Theorica et practica
works.author: Arnold de Villanova

persons.name: Thomas AndrewKnight
persons.description: Knight was a botanist and horticulturalist. He was the second president of the Royal Horticulture Society. Davy frequently fished on Knight's esates in the Welsh Marches. FRSL.

persons.name: Charles FrancisGreville
persons.description: A British antiquarian, collector and politician who sat in the House of Commons from 1774 to 1790. FRSL.

persons.name: William HaseldinePepys
persons.description: Pepys was a surgical and scientific instrument maker and chemist. Constructed large batteries used by Davy (amongst others). FRSL.

persons.name: RichardKnight
persons.description: Brother of George who were both scientific instrument makers based in Foster Lane, Cheapside, London.

places.name: Cornwall
places.description: Cornwall is a county in south-west England, birthplace of Humphry Davy.

persons.name: ThomasThomson
persons.description: Scottish chemist and mineralogist whose writings contributed to the early spread of Dalton's atomic theory. FRSL.

persons.name: ThomasThomson
persons.description: Scottish chemist and mineralogist whose writings contributed to the early spread of Dalton's atomic theory. FRSL.

places.name: Mucrish
places.description: Muckish, one of the Derryveagh Mountains. See the poem 'Mucrish and Arokil, ye pair...' in Tait's Edinburgh Magazine for 1836, vol. iii, p. 252. See also Memoirs, vol. 1, pp. 287 ff.

places.name: Donegal
places.description: Donegal is a town at the mouth of the River Eske, in north-west Ireland.

places.name: Arakil
places.description: Arokil is the Errigal mountain of the same range; the handwriting on page 69 in notebook 15B was reproduced by John Davy along with the poem 'Mucrish and Arokil, ye pair...' in Tait's Edinburgh Magazine for 1836, vol. iii, p. 252. See also Memoirs, vol. 1, pp. 287 ff.

persons.name: JohnHampden-Trevor
persons.description: John Hampden-Trevor, 3rd Viscount Hampden was a British diplomat. Davy wrote a poem 'To Mr & Mrs Trevor.' in notebooks 13G and 13J which John Davy republished in Fragmentary Remains, p. 117.

places.name: Athens
places.description: Athens is the capital city of Greece.

places.name: Cyprus
places.description: Cyprus is the third largest and third-most populous island in the Mediterranean. It is east of Greece, north of Egypt, south of Turkey, and west of Lebanon and Syria. Cyprus occupies an important role in Greek mythology, being the birthplace of Aphrodite and Adonis, and home to King Cinyras, Teucer and Pygmalion.

places.name: Athens
places.description: Athens is the capital city of Greece.

places.name: Athens
places.description: Athens is the capital city of Greece.

persons.name: AnnaBeddoes
persons.description: Anna Beddoes, née Edgeworth, the wife of Thomas Beddoes who befriended Davy when he arrived in Bristol. Critics have speculated that they had an affair because Davy wrote poems to Anna and she wrote poems for him that he copied out in his notebooks.

places.name: Glenarm
places.description: Glenarm, a village and castle in County Antrim, Northern Ireland. Davy wrote a poem called 'Glenarm', dated August 1806.

places.name: River Severn
places.description: At 220 miles long, the longest river in Great Britain.

places.name: River Avon
places.description: The River Avon in central England flows generally south-westwards and is a major left-bank tributary of the River Severn.

persons.name: RogerBacon
persons.description: Medieval English philosopher and Franciscan friar.

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.
